_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: TDI contact with moisture/water, loss of plant nitrogen supply, TDI incompatibility with other chemicals present in the common vapor system.
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Tank fill restrictions due to high specific gravity, external / mineral oil heating, N2, carbon drums on vapor lines, separate vapor system at R-2, dessicant system on conservation vent, radar gauges
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Quarterly leak detection and repair (LDAR) program for vapor lines. Camera network viewable in 24-hour Operations Control Room.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: PHA Updated in February 2015 for D-Tank Farm TDI Storage. No changes since last PHA update.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Routine Preventative Maintenance Inspection of the Tank Farm Vent Flare (Express Maintenance Work Order 141772)

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: No Nitrogen Pad in ISO Container Being Loaded
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Nitrogen Pad on ISO Container Prior to Loading to Ensure an Inert Atmosphere.  Automated Shut-Down of the Flare System.
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Permanent and Portable Fire Water /Foam Delivery Systems.  Portable Fire Extinguishers.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Quarterly leak detection and repair (LDAR) program. Camera network viewable in 24-hour Operations Control Room.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Increased Isopentane Chemical Inventory Based on Number of Rail Cars Held on Storage Tracks Simultaneously.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Routine Preventative Maintenance Inspection of the Tank Farm Vent Flare (Express Maintenance Work Order 141772)

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Loss of Inhibitor, Loss of Nitrogen Blanket, Polymerization in Marine Flare System
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Stored in an Internal Floating Roof Tank, Nitrogen Blanketing System on Tank, Dedicated Marine Dock Line, SAAB Radar Gauge, Hermetic Gauge/Sample System, Vapor System Purges, Flared Loading
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Permanent and Portable Water / Foam Delivery Systems.  Fire-Fighting Water Delivery Monitors Installed South of Tank P50-5.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Quarterly leak detection and repair (LDAR) program. Camera network viewable in 24-hour Operations Control Room.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: VAM Storage commenced in two additional tanks (P40-1 & P50-4).  Flammable chemicals (n-Propanol) stored in adjacent tanks.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Routine Maintenance Inspection of VAM Storage Tank Internal Floating Roofs

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: American Petroleum Institute (API) Standard for Valve Reconditioning
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Pump seal failure.  Thermal expansion in idle dock line during rail car switching.
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Nitrogen purge placed on affected systems prior to commencing transfer operations.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Permanent and Portable Water / Foam Delivery Systems.  Portable Fire Extinguishers.
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Quarterly leak detection and repair (LDAR) program. Camera network viewable in 24-hour Operations Control Room.
_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: Computer Based Training ("CBT") Modules. Question and Answer session amongst area-trained operators experienced in performing flammable liquid transfers.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Marine Flare for Ship Dock 2/3 and McGill Flare for Rail Rack R-3

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PURPOSE FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION / UPDATE

Stolthaven Houston Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan ("RMP") in May of 2018 as a result of recent changes to the facility's P-Tank Farm Covered Process that required a revised Process Hazard Analysis, and to revise various RMP data elements that have changed since the previous plan update submitted in June of 2016.  The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:

- The inclusion of two additional Vinyl Acetate Monomer storage tanks located in P-Tank Farm (Tank P40-1 and Tank P50-4),

- Representing the completion of a new Process Hazard Analysis performed as a result of commencing the storage of flammable liquids not specifically listed in Tables 1-4 of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 ("40 CFR 68") in tanks located in close proximity to Stolthaven Houston's three P-Tank Farm Vinyl Acetate Monomer storage tanks, and 

- Various RMP data element updates based on revisions to Stolthaven Houston's Emergency Action Plan ("EAP") and our Standard Operating Procedures ("SOP") found in the terminal's Local Training Manual ("LTM"). 


§ 68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Stolthaven Houston Inc. is committed to operating and maintaining our processes related to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  The facility uses a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees, our industrial neighbors, and the citizens of the surrounding community.  This Executive Summary provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston Inc. has designed and implemented, including:

- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by 40 CFR 68 that may be handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding threshold quantities

- An ov

erview of our accidental release prevention programs

- A five-year history of significant accidental releases from processes covered by the Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") RMP regulations

- An overview of our emergency response programs

- An overview of improvements implemented at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets, and

- Detailed information about our Risk Management Program


§ 68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Stolthaven Houston Inc. owns and operates a bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 188 above-ground storage tanks that vary in capacity from 2,000-barrels up to 110,000-barrels, five truck loading/unloading racks (Truck Racks T-3, T-4, T-5, T-6 and T-8), four rail car loading/unloading racks (Rail Racks R-1, R-2, R-3 and R-5), one barge dock (Barge Dock-C), and a finger pier jetty equipped with two separate marine vessel berths used for handling barges and ships (Ship Dock 2/3).  A rail car cleaning and intermodal transfer station (Rail Rack R-4 and Truck Rack T-7) is also located within the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and a biological waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are operated on-site to reduce the impact of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's operations on the environment.

Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal by various modes of transportation cargo container including tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, rail tank cars, barges, and marine parcel tankers.  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequently transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transportation m

odes.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. also performs direct product transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars with no intermediate storage in the facility's above-ground storage tanks.  Similarly, land-based intermodal ("IMO") transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthaven Houston Inc. does not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control the disposition of the various bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.

The following chemicals handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause off-site consequences in the event of a significant accidental release:

Regulated Toxic Substances Currently in Storage:

Toluene Diisocyanate ("TDI"), Mixed Isomers:  Chemical Abstracts Service ("CAS") Number 26471-62-5
Vinyl Acetate Monomer ("VAM"):  CAS Number 108-05-4

Regulated Flammable Substance Currently Handled via Intermodal Transfer (Rail Cars to ISO Containers):

Isopentane:  CAS Number 78-78-4

Regulated Flammable Substance Currently Handled via Direct Transfers (Marine Vessels to/from Rail Cars):

n-Pentane (CAS Number 109-66-0, Present in Two Separate Mixtures Containing up to 16.13-percent n-Pentane)

TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulated substances at Stolthaven Houston Inc. that are present on-site above their corresponding threshold quantities at all times.  Isopentane is periodically transloaded directly from rail tank cars into ISO tank containers with no intermediate on-site storage, other than loaded rail cars temporarily staged on the terminal's storage tracks prior to performing the IMO transfer.  As a result, Isopentane is not always present above the threshold quantity at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Similarly, Stolthave

n Houston Inc. also performs periodic direct transfers between marine vessels and rail cars of two mixtures that may contain up to 16.13-percent n-Pentane.  Like the Isopentane intermodal transfers, the two n-Pentane mixtures are on-site only during the actual direct transfer operation, and while loaded rail cars are held on Stolthaven Houston's rail car storage tracks prior to, or immediately after, performing the transfer.  The majority of the time the Stolthaven Houston Terminal will not have n-Pentane on-site above the 10,000-pound threshold quantity.

Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures ("SOP") and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment during the storage and/or transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated chemicals.

TOLUENE DIISOCYANATE STORAGE AND TRANSFERS

Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently stores TDI in one 30,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tank (Low-Pressure Storage Tank D30-10) and in two 15,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tanks (Low-Pressure Storage Tanks D15-19 and D15-22).  Tank D30-10 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 10,600,000-pounds (1,042,000-gallons).  Tank D15-19 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,122,000-pounds (503,600-gallons).  Tank D15-22 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,131,000-pounds (504,500-gallons).  TDI is received into the facility for storage via delivery by marine parcel tankers, tank trucks, and rail cars; TDI is shipped outbound from Stolthaven Houston Inc. by rail cars and marine parcel tankers.  Periodic direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels into rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston Inc. with no intermediate product storage in the three referenced D-Tank Farm storage tanks.  Note that Stolth

aven Houston Inc. has over 23-years of experience in the storage and handling of TDI. 

As part of the most recent changes associated with additional TDI storage in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D15-19, significant modifications were performed such that TDI is handled safely and efficiently in this tank, including installing a liner on the storage tank's floor and shell, installing a line constructed of 316L stainless steel from the storage tank to the existing marine dock line in D-Manifold used exclusively for TDI marine-based transfers, replacing all existing gate valves on the Tank D15-19 system with ball valves for ease of operation, installing a stainless-steel pump for TDI at Storage Tank D15-19, installing hot water external heating panels, a water tank, and associated heating panel supply/return lines for Storage Tank D15-19 while in TDI service, insulating Tank D15-19, installing internal eductors at the tank's recirculation line to improve product mixing, installing electric heat tracing and insulation on the tank's lateral line to D-Manifold, installing a dehydrator on the tank's vacuum breaker to help prevent moisture from entering the vapor space should there be a loss of plant nitrogen, and installing a carbon adsorption canister on the Storage Tank D15-19 vapor line prior to TDI vapors entering the terminal's common Tank Farm Vent Flare vapor header to reduce the concentration of TDI in the system.  

ISOPENTANE INTERMODAL TRANSFERS

Isopentane is periodically transloaded directly between rail tank cars spotted at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's Rail Rack R-2 into ISO tank containers located at Truck Rack T-6 with no intermediate product storage in any of the terminal's chemical storage tanks.  Vapors generated during these intermittent Isopentane transfer operations are directed to the Tank Farm Vent Flare for vapor control.  During calendar year 2017 85-separate Isopentane IMO loading events were completed at Racks R-2 and T-6.

During the fi

rst quarter of 2018 Stolthaven Houston initiated Change Management Procedures to potentially relocate these Isopentane IMO transfers between Rail Rack R-5 and Truck Rack T-8 in an effort to reduce carrier delays and relieve congestion associated with heavy truck loading and unloading activity for other cargos handled at Truck Rack T-6.  As of the May 2018 RMP update, certain tasks identified during the Change Management process, which included adding automation equipment and associated programming on the proposed intermodal transfer line between Rail Rack R-5 and Truck Rack T-8, have not been completed; the proposed change in Isopentane IMO operations has not occurred.  

VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS

Storage Tank P50-5 is an existing internal floating roof ("IFR") tank at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of approximately 50,142-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16,400,000-pounds.  Tank P50-5, which represents the facility's worst-case release scenario, was placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is stored and then shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers and occasionally barges that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Ship Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges into rail tank cars with no intermediate product storage, and VAM slops can also be received into the terminal from marine vessels berthed at Stolthaven Houston.  

In November of 2017 Stolthaven Houston placed IFR Storage Tank P50-4 in VAM service for the first time.  Tank P50-4 has a working capacity of approximately 48,651-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 15,800,000-pounds.  As a result of the 2017 VAM storage project for Tank P50-4, piping modifications were completed in P-Ma

nifold to connect the marine transfer system for Tank P50-4 into the existing dock line in place for VAM Tank P50-5.  A new VAM filter-pot was also installed adjacent to the storage tank.

On March 2, 2018 Stolthaven Houston placed IFR Storage Tank P40-1 in VAM service for the first time.  Tank P40-1 has a working capacity of approximately 38,177-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 12,500,000-pounds.  Storage Tank P40-1 had a dedicated marine dock line in place before VAM storage commenced.  As such, the Tank P40-1 VAM system is independent from the Tank P50-4 and P50-5 VAM systems, though all three tanks are located in P-Tank Farm.  VAM may be received and shipped outbound from IFR Storage Tank P40-1

Note that the Tank P50-4 and Tank P40-1 storage projects did not change the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's worst-case release scenario for VAM, as the maximum quantity of this material held in any one tank did not increase; existing IFR Storage Tank P50-5 continues to have the largest inventory of VAM in storage.  Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water if-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the the facility's flammable or combustible liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.

N-PENTANE MIXTURE DIRECT TRANSFERS

Stolthaven Houston periodically performs direct transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars of two unique mixtures that contain n-Pentane.  The first mixture is a blend of various Hexane isomers (commonly referred to as "Isohexanes") that can contain up to 10-percent n-Pentane by volume; this stream will be transferred from rail cars spotted at Stolthaven Houston's Rail Rack R-3 directly into a marine vessel berthed at Stolthaven Houston's Ship

Dock 2/3 using either the R3-A1-D3-42 Direct Transfer Line or the R3-A1-D3-41 Direct Transfer Line.  Vapors generated at the marine vessel during direct transfer operations will be controlled using the facility's Marine Loading Flare.  Prior to conducting the direct transfer operation, the dock line and all transfer hoses must be pre-conditioned with product in order to reduce the risk of contamination during transfer.  Additionally, the direct transfer dock line, all transfer hoses, and the ship's cargo tank will be cleaned, inspected, and purged using plant nitrogen to below 500-parts per million ("ppm") oxygen content prior to commencing the product movement.  Rail Rack R-3 at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal is an 8-spot system; as such, up to 8-rail cars can be connected to the direct transfer line simultaneously.  As of the May 2018 RMP update, Stolthaven Houston has performed just two direct transfers of Isohexanes:  one transfer in July of 2015 and one transfer in July of 2016.  

The second mixture (Manufacturer's Trade Name "Kogasol 56") is a C5-C6 paraffin and alkane blend rich in n-Hexane that can contain up to 16.13-percent n-Pentane by volume; this stream will be transferred from a marine vessel berthed at Stolthaven Houston's Ship Dock 2/3 into a maximum of 8-rail cars spotted at Stolthaven Houston's Rail Rack R-3 using either the R3-A1-D3-42 Direct Transfer Line or the R3-A1-D3-41 Direct Transfer Line.  Vapors generated at the rail rack during direct transfer operations are controlled using the facility's McGill Truck and Rail Car Loading Flare.  Similar to the Isohexane stream, the direct transfer dock line and hoses must be pre-conditioned using material from an advance rail car containing n-Pentane; liquid is pushed into the transfer hoses and lines, and is ultimately transferred into a vacuum truck in order to reduce the risk of product contamination during the actual transfer operation from ship to rail cars.  The direct transfer dock line, al

l transfer hoses, and the rail cars will be clean, inspected, and purged using plant nitrogen to below 500-ppm oxygen content prior to commencing the product movement.  As of the May 2018 RMP update, Stolthaven Houston has performed just three direct transfers of Kogasol 56:  one transfer in June of 2016, one transfer in December of 2016, and one transfer in February of 2017.  

Employee training related to the Kogasol 56 / n-Pentane direct transfer processes was completed for Stolthaven Houston Marine Dock and Rail Rack R-1/R-3 Operations Personnel on June 21, 2016 and June 23, 2016.  In an abundance of caution, for the purpose of worst-case release scenario modeling, full rail car volumes assuming 100-percent n-Pentane were applied.  In reality, a maximum of approximately 16-percent n-Pentane is present in these direct transfer mixtures.  

   
§ 68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:

- Process Safety Information ("PSI")

- Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA")

- ISO 9001:2015 Certified Quality Management System ("QMS")

- Employee Training / LTM

- Mechanical Integrity Program

- Spill Containment and Countermeasures

- Management of Change ("MOC")

- Pre-Startup Safety Review ("PSSR")

- Vapor Control Systems

- Compliance Audits

- Formal Incident Investigation

- Employee Participation Program

- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits

- Departmental / Safety Meetings

- Emergency Response Team ("ERT")

- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors

- Ongoing automation enhancements

The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management system

s set for the way we conduct business, and we have controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.


§ 68.155(d):  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the preceding five years there has been one accidental release from a RMP covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal which resulted in significant property damage on-site.  On the evening of August 23, 2013 nitrogen pressure was being used to unload a rail car containing TDI into one of Stolthaven Houston's three D-Tank Farm TDI storage tanks.  As the rail car was being unloaded, the rail switching crew on-duty coupled the terminal's locomotive to a string of rail cars, including the working TDI rail car, and began to pull the cars away from the rail rack.  As the rail car being emptied of TDI was moved from the unloading spot, the TDI cargo hose released from the top of rail car, and the 1-inch valve connected to the plant nitrogen hose was sheared off of the rail car.  Nitrogen pressure in the rail car caused approximately 4,500-gallons of TDI to be released from the sheared 1-inch valve opening on the top of the rail car into the Rail Rack R-2 concrete containment area, with a small amount of liquid TDI released onto an in-plant concrete road adjacent to the Rail Rack R-2 in the center of the facility.  There was no off-site release of TDI liquid.  A Stolthaven Houston operator on duty at the rail rack immediately closed the rail rack TDI product line valve leading to the storage tank being filled, and the TDI liquid release from the rail car stopped once the residual nitrogen pressure in the car reached atmospheric pressure.  A third-party environmental response contractor was contacted within an hour of this release to assist with the necessary clean-up efforts, which were completed on the late afternoon of August 27, 2013.

As a result of this incident, the following corrective actions were implemented by Stolthaven Houston Inc. after review by the terminal'

s Management Steering Committee:  (1) the TDI incident was discussed in detail at a mandatory meeting conducted at Rail Rack R-2 for all facility Operations, Waste Water, and Maintenance Department personnel, (2) Standard Operating Procedures related to rail car switching were formally updated on September 20, 2013, and (3) operator training related to the revised rail car switching and blue flag procedures was conducted during Operations Departmental meetings held according to shift schedule during September of 2013.  

Note that this incident did not result in any on-site deaths or injuries.  Similarly, there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered processes in the past five years which resulted in known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

All incidents at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our facility's ISO QMS to identify and correct the root cause(s) of the events, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.


§ 68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Stolthaven Houston maintains a Facility Response Plan ("FRP") with the United States Coast Guard, Houston-Galveston Sector. Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Local Emergency Planning Committee ("LEPC").  Stolthaven Houston's hazardous chemical inventory report (i.e. Tier II report) is maintained current with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality ("TCEQ"), the North Channel LEPC, and the local Channelview, Texas Fi

re Department.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. is also a member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid ("CIMA").    

An Emergency Action Plan ("EAP") is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personnel injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.   


§ 68.155(f):  CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of completed and planned/ongoing initiatives at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to assist in preventing and/or responding to accidental chemical releases, and to help effectively manage the hazards present at the facility:

- In 2014 a new role, Emergency Response Coordinator, was created and filled to the streamline the terminal's response efforts in the event of a significant incident at the facility

- As they are emptied and cleaned, storage tanks with the potential to store toxic and/or flammable liquids are being equipped with quick-closing ball valves to replace existing gate valves as part of ongoing safety enhancements and automation efforts, which include status alarms displayed in the terminal's 24-hour Operations Control Room, and actuated valve closures based on high tank inventory levels.

- Double verification of all line and hose connections before commencing any product transfer operations to reduce the possibility of incorrect valve/hose alignment

- A complete review, hydraulic study, and engineering analysis of Stolthaven Houston's fire water delivery systems

- Portable fire water delivery and foam making systems purchased

- Continuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001:2015 Certified QMS

- Employee Suggestion / Experience Feedback Program

- Regular safety meetings with Stolthaven Houston Operations Department employees and contract personnel working in the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, 

- Relocating the facility's Fire House away from plant operating areas that could potenti

ally be affected in the event of an emergency at the facility 

- Replacement of all fire-fighting hoses

- Purchase of a rehab trailer for use in the event of a significant incident on-site

- Fall protection added at all transfer racks where trucks and ISO containers are loaded and unloaded

Additional capital budget projects under consideration for future improvements to safety and emergency response at Stolthaven Houston Inc. include the purchase of additional fire-fighting equipment and PPE for the company's emergency response team personnel, additional surveillance cameras to be installed around the terminal's east expansion property, and adding concrete paving to five existing tank farms (A, B, F, S, and Q) that currently have earthen floors to improve both secondary containment capability and surface working conditions for employees.
